unnormalised: So, someone asked about understanding our crazy Indian grading system. Buckle up, buttercups, because it's a wild ride! We've got everything from the oh-so-coveted 100% (basically, you're Einstein reborn) to the dreaded 33% (a.k.a. "kiss of death," also known as the pass mark, somehow). And don't even get me started on the CGPA scale!

And don't even get me started on the C-G-P-A scale!

unnormalised: Think of it like this: you toil away, cramming textbooks at 2 AM, fueled by instant noodles and chai (because sleep is for the weak). Then, comes the exam. A 3-hour brain dump where you pray to every deity you know just to scrape by. Your future, allegedly, depends on this single numerical value. Talk about pressure! I remember this one time in 10th grade, I got a 92.5% in Science. My mom was like, "Why not 93? What happened to the .5%?" No chill, I tell ya!

A three-hour brain dump where you pray to every deity you know just to scrape by. Your future, allegedly, depends on this single numerical value. Talk about pressure! I remember this one time in tenth grade, I got a ninety two point five percent in Science. My mom was like, "Why not ninety three? What happened to the point five percent?" No chill, I tell ya!

unnormalised: The funny thing is, marks aren’t everything, right? I mean, sure, getting a high score in your 12th boards – say, 98% – opens doors, but does it guarantee success in life? Nah. You'll meet people with a mere 50% who are running their own startups and living the dream. So, don't lose sleep over that 75% if you feel like something's missing in your learning.

unnormalised: And the sheer variety! Some schools use letter grades (A+, B, C-), others stick to percentages. Some calculate averages; some weight certain subjects more than others. And don’t even get me started on the confusing conversions from CBSE marks to state board marks, or ICSE to CBSE. It's all one big numerical circus! The cutoffs for colleges are also hilarious. You need 99.9999% to get into Delhi University for some courses, it feels like.
